My wife does this shit, I have a strategy. First, I get increasingly irritated the more questions she asks, while answering "no you're not fat" or whatever answer she obviously is looking for. >Why do you need to ask it multiple ways?
>Haven't I answered this already?
>Are you trying to get me to tell me you're fat? It seems like you're not satisfied with the answers I'm giving

>I'm just expressing sympathy, isn't that OK?
She hasn't found a way around that yet.

The key is to change the subject to her and why she's asking the questions. These kinds of "people" who believe they are entitled to compelled behaviors from others HATE looking in the mirror, so you need to change the topic back to them. threads.com:
>no new thread for over two hours
lazy fucks

Staying up all night edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For ducks and nuns who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

It's complicated. But basically, your hormones trigger lipolysis, which causes your adipose tissue to release fatty acids into the bloodstream.
This usually only happens when your body thinks it's running low on glucose, but hormones are fucking complicated.

>will i see that on the scale the next monday or will i need to wait until, say wednesday or thursday for the body to catch up?
Your weight fluctuates for a whole bunch of reasons. Water retention. How much waste is in your bowel. How much CO2 have you breathed out. etc.
Hyperfixating on daily or intradaily movements isn't effective. You need to look at trends.

>Advice for new runners (if you already have good cardio and fitness you can skip this)
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- If you can comfortably run 6 miles at one time, start thinking about what your goal race is, and look for a training routine for that race.

What’s worked for me is this.

Start a weight you can do for 3x8 until you are almost at failure on the last set. Next session or week, depending on how fast you progress, do 3x10 same weight. Then 3x12, 4x8, 4x10x and 4x12. You are adding reps each session, progressively overloading your muscles workload each session (ideally). Then, once you do 4x12, increase weight to a range where you can do 3x8, repeat. Works good for me

last_replies.com:
>>69124356
There are a lot of good cues, but I would start by reducing the weight/intensity of your back exercises. People have a bad habit of using egolifting weight in exercises like bent over rows, cable rows, cable pulldowns, etc, and this makes it very difficult to correctly activate the lats/back or hold correct position and form, and it has a way of making biceps and shoulders take over. One big difficult pill a lot of young lifters have to swallow is that bodybuilding means you have to swallow your pride a lot of the time and lift light but focused... just because you can row 225 doesn't mean you should or that it will grow your back compared to 135.

Some good cues for lats activation:
>do scap pullups (look them up) to strengthen scap muscles and learn how to selectively activate them. Focus on retracting and moving scaps during your lats work, and if you find that your shoulders remain protracted (shrugged up/forward) through the whole movement of rows/pulldowns, you are using too much weight. Use a weight that allows you to move your scaps out and in
>for lats, focus on the concentric portion of the exercise as "crushing oranges in your armpits". This applies not only to rows/pulldowns, but also any pressing exercise like bench or dips where you are retracting your scaps and activating your lats to support your shoulder. This is also true of deadlifts/RDL
>keep your elbows tucked for rows/pulldowns, i.e. do work in the scapular plane for pulldown work and keep your elbows closer to your sides for rowing work. As part of the "crushing oranges" cue, drive your elbows to your waist/obliques during rows/pulldowns to activate lats

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69124356
>>69124816
Oh also a big redpill is that when you're doing proper form for all your exercises, every day is "back day", i.e. legs, shoulders, chest, biceps, triceps exercises should all be recruiting the back in a big way.
>For squats, you should be "pulling the bar through your back", which is just a way to activate your lats to contribute to torso rigidity. After leg day, my lats feel just as sore as after back day
>For bench, dips, incline press, or a lot of pressing work excluding OHP, your lats should be contracted with full force to stabilize your shoulders and hold them back/down in a safe, sturdy position. Your lats should feel a bit sore after pressing days if you are using good form
>For biceps work, your lats/scaps should be stabilizing your shoulders back/down for good form, and for many curls variations your lats should be activated to pull your elbows close to your sides
>DL and RDL should have you "crushing oranges in your armpits" and your scaps retracted, which works the upper back a lot more than people like to think

This is all just a way to say that most upper body exercises require you to stabilize your shoulders back and down and depress your scaps, which means lats and scapular muscles are being worked

Been lifting for bout a month now. Is the progression alright?

Starting weights
>benching the bar for 12
>OHPing the bar for 12
>squating the bar for 10
>deadlifting 95lbs for 5

What I lift as of this week
>benching 100 lbs for 10
>OHPing 130 lbs for 8
>squating 125 lbs for 7
>deadlifting 225 for 5
I do more exercises than this but these are the big compounds people talk about when discussing lifting

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
100% ignore anyone who says either yes or no. Progression is entirely individual. A 130lb person with no muscle mass and no history of athletic activity is going to make way less progress than a 220lb fat guy who has some muscle from carrying around fat all day and used to play football in high school. Unless you're comparing to someone with very similar body and history it's pointless.

Are you pushing yourself within a rep of failure?
Are you eating enough for your goals (mass gain vs fat loss)?
Are you sleeping enough?
No smoking or excessive alcohol?
Good form on lifts?
(Optional) gotten blood work to check your test/e2/cortisol levels?

If those all check out, keep doing what you're doing if you're making progress. If you're not making progress, you've probably plateaued and will be making further progress slowly, or switch routine to one that is more suited to your goals.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69124490
A nice variation is suicide 50's. It's still EMOM, but your time MUST decrease by at least 1 second every lap, i.e. first lap you get back by 60s, second lap by 59, etc. When you fail you active rest a little bit and hit the next set.

Also, sprint 25s actually let you completely unleash. Also do them EMOM and incorporate with sprint kick. Typically looks like
(warm up)
8x25 sprint kick EMOM
active rest
8x25 sprint swim EMOM
active rest
repeat
Also compare the combined time with that achieved in a meet environment (ie sum of first four cf. your 100m time). the summed time should be faster and should be your next meet goal time.

also, if you want to do a 90-minute sprint workout your sprint sets will still comprise very little of that actual time. Do a lot of warmup and active rest.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: I'm reading about drinking water before/while/after eating. I've got 2 different answers that you should or shouldn't do that. What is your opinion on this topic fit?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This is completely from personal experience with no scientific or medical, (yes I did exclude medicine from science deal with it), rationale.

Food should be eaten without water. The acidity and temperature of the stomach is important in digestion
When you dump cold water in there is takes some time to get thing reorganized. Food should be chewed for a long period of time before swallowing. It should be a paste with no large pieces. That's why we have molars.
After a meal wait approximately 2 hours before drinking water. That should get the stomach enough time to move everything into the small intestine for extraction. At that point, water may assist in the absorption process.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69124209
Water is objectively a good thing that your body needs, especially if you exercise frequently. Plus drinking water before/after your meals is good if you’re trying to achieve a deficit, since it helps you feel more full. Plus it’ll help with digestion. Just be sure to consume some salt with you food as well if you plan on doing this.

Before some dumbass says “oVeRhYdRaTiOn”, that shit is way harder to achieve than you think. Like forcing yourself to drink a gallon when your body is already telling you to stop. An extra 16 ounces over the course of your meal isn’t going to kill you.
